I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the efforts of the 
developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to build livable cities 
that are green, competitive, inclusive, and resilient by applying innovative and integrated solutions 
in project development, design, and execution.1 Under the One ADB approach, the TA team will 
work in close collaboration with various sector and thematic groups, and operations departments 
of ADB and DMCs to capture knowledge of planning, implementing, and operating livable cities.  
 
2.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and its Operational Plan for Priority 4: Making 
Cities More Livable, 2019−2024, which aims to improve the coverage, quality, efficiency, and 
reliability of services in urban areas; strengthen urban planning and the financial sustainability of 
cities; and improve the urban environment, climate resilience, and disaster risk management of 
cities.2 It is being developed in close consultation with ADB operations departments and has been 
supported by the Urban Sector Group Committee (comprising of directors from the operations 
departments). Additionally, it will build on lessons from previous activities of ADB’s regional 
departments,  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change  Department,  and  urban 
development initiatives at other multilateral development organizations.3 The TA is included in the 
Management-approved 2019  results-based  work  plan  of  the  Sustainable  Development  and 
Climate Change Department. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Urbanization and deficient services. Urbanization, especially in developing countries, 
is one of the most significant global trends that will define the future. The urban population in Asia 
and the Pacific increased from about 20% of the region’s population in the 1950s to about 
48% in 2018, and is projected to be about 55% or 2.5 billion people in 2030.4 Cities have high 
potential to act as catalyst for economic development, contributing about 70% of the region’s 
gross  domestic  product.  Urbanization  is  often  linked  to  improved  economic  opportunities, 
increased access to health and education services, and better living conditions.5 At the same time, 
cities face the challenges of uncontrollably rapid rates of urbanization, growing infrastructure 
                                                
1   A generally understood concept for a city to become more livable is to apply an integrated planning approach to the 
provision of infrastructure and services and other public goods based on economic competitiveness, environmentally 
sustainable growth, social and financial inclusion, and resilience. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities 
section of ADB’s website on 26 April 2019. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila; ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Priority 4: Making Cities More Livable, 2019–2024. Manila.  
3  The TA team will consider lessons from similar city action plans and TA projects from ADB and other development 
organizations, including but not limited to the following:  
  ADB. 2019. Creating Livable Cities: Regional Perspectives. Manila.  
  ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance to Georgia for Preparing Integrated Solutions for Livable Cities. Manila. 
  ADB. 2016. GrEEEn Solutions for Livable Cities. Manila.  
    ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance for Promoting Smart Systems in ADB’s Future Cities Program. Manila.  
  ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for Establishing the Future Cities Program in the Asia and Pacific Region. Manila.   
  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Green Cities–A Sustainable Urban Future in Southeast Asia. Manila. The main 
lessons include selecting cities and projects with real potential, focusing on the development of cities’ internal 
capacities, and employing multisectoral and cross-thematic approaches, among others. The TA team will also study 
other urban initiatives by multilateral development organizations such as the European Bank of Reconstruction and 
Development’s Green City, Inter-American Development Bank’s City Lab, and Organisation for Economic Co-
operation and Development’s City Innovation.   
4  United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division. 2018.  World Urbanization 
Prospects: The 2018 Revision. New York.   
5   ADB. 2011. Asia 2050: Realizing the Asian Century. Manila.

2 
deficits, increasing risks of climate change and disasters, environmental stress, traffic congestion, 
aging societies, growing inequality, violence and crime, uncertainties associated with rapid 
technology advances, and emerging threats such as cyberattacks and terrorism. As of 2016, 
523 million people across Asia and the Pacific live in informal settlements with poor services, 
260 million people have no access to safe drinking water, and 1.7 billion lack basic sanitation.6 
Moreover, the region’s cities discharge 80% of the wastewater they generate into water bodies 
without primary treatment, while the region is expected to generate 1.8 billion tons of waste per 
year by 2025.7   
 
4.  Weak urban planning, institutions, and governance hurt delivery of infrastructure 
and  services.  Cities  in  DMCs  need  to  build  adequate  institutional  capacity  for  planning, 
implementing,  and  operating  urban  infrastructure  and  services,  and for  solving  their  urban 
problems. Further, cities and urban regions, particularly small and medium-sized cities and towns, 
frequently face governance challenges, including weak institutional structures, overlapping legal 
and regulatory frameworks, lack of coordination, blurred administrative boundaries, corruption, 
poor public services, lack of own-source revenue, and capacity constraints, despite the increasing 
level of decentralization. Implementation often takes place in the cities while the decisions are 
made at higher levels, leading to suboptimal problem solving. Mobilizing citizens, partners, and 
other stakeholders for planning, design, and implementation helps build inclusive governance 
systems for people-centered and needs-based livable city solutions.  
 
5.  Financial sustainability of service provision and urban improvement projects needs 
to be achieved. Urban infrastructure finance is often challenged by the absence of creditworthy 
entities, opaque credit structures, insufficient own-source revenues, and poor cost-recovery 
mechanisms compounded by the reluctance of the governments and urban agencies to levy user 
charges. The key local sources of revenue, such as property taxes, publicly owned assets, 
and licenses remain underutilized or undeveloped, while many DMCs are facing debt limits and 
other financial constraints. Robust financial management systems and fundamental tools such as 
a cadaster system, property registry, and utility metering system need to be strengthened.   
 
6.  Weak understanding of smart systems or applications of digital technology as a 
critical component in urban solution provision. Cities in DMCs lack adequate expertise in 
smart8 systems or digital technology such as network systems, information and communication 
technology, Internet of Things9, and the use of sensors, which generate tremendous opportunities 
for enhancing efficiency, economy, and impact when they are thoughtfully implemented with 
urban infrastructure and service delivery. Such solutions also support city governance and 
engagement  with  citizens  and  other  stakeholders.  Moreover,  data  analytics  and  artificial 
intelligence  help  cities  understand  their  strengths,  weaknesses,  and  opportunities  for 
improvement,  while  facilitating  data-  and  evidence-based  decision-making.  Proven,  new, 
and emerging digital technologies provide unprecedented opportunities for cities to leapfrog to 
the level of developed cities and achieve transformation rapidly and efficiently.    
 
7.  Poor  livability  affects  competitiveness,  and  lack  of  competitiveness  impacts 
livability. A competitive city creates large markets; acts like a magnet attracting investments, 
                                                
6   Informal settlement figure corresponds to urban, while water supply and sanitation correspond to urban and rural.  
7   ADB. 2016. Asian Water Development Outlook 2016: Strengthening Water Security in Asia and the Pacific. Manila; 
and United Nations Environment Programme. 2017. Asia Waste Management Outlook. Nairobi.  
8  “Smart” in the context of urban development refers to the use of new technologies and digital solutions. "Innovative 
solution" therefore is a larger term that includes smart technology.  
9  The interconnection via the Internet of computing devices embedded in everyday objects, enabling them to send and 
receive data without requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction.

3 
knowledge, talent, skills, and management; and generates new ideas, well-paying jobs, economic 
opportunities,  and  wealth.  The  competitiveness  of  cities  goes  far  beyond  the  provision  of 
infrastructure and public services and includes an enabling environment to attract investments in 
manufacturing and services necessary to create and sustain dynamic markets and generate jobs 
for the increasing labor force. Poor livability discourages entrepreneurship, employment, creativity, 
and innovation, and deters investments in and opportunities for cities to act as economic engines 
that bring long-term productivity and stability.   
 
8.  Transformative  opportunity.  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  and  Operational  Plan  for 
Priority 4: Making Cities More Livable (footnote 2) provide an opportunity to help cities become 
more livable. For cities, “livability” may be defined differently based on their stages of development 
and long-term vision. Nevertheless, for citizens, aspirations for opportunities to improve the quality 
of life and standards of living are universal. Urban space, which embodies unlimited opportunities 
for human advancement, is innately complex, calling for efforts to increase livability through 
integrated  solutions,  which  require  multisector  and  cross-thematic  approaches,  adequate 
institutional capacities, and sound governance systems.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  urban  livability  in  DMCs  improved 
(footnote 2). The TA will have the following outcome: integrated and innovative urban solutions 
promoted.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Plans for enhancing livability in select cities developed. This will include  
(i) capturing and structuring knowledge of past and ongoing operations in select cities in DMCs 
to inform the design of future projects for livable cities, (ii) developing inclusive and gender 
responsive city action plans for achieving long-term goals, and (iii) producing recommendations 
on innovative methodologies for city action plans and ways to mainstream such methodologies in 
ADB operations. The TA team will produce the plans in the form of livable city action plans 
leveraging various available frameworks and methodologies based on long-term goals, the 
assessment of current needs, and available resources.11 The plans may include a mix of various 
components such as infrastructure and service provision; institutional strengthening, capacity 
development,  and  knowledge  management;  planning,  governance,  and  finance;  use  of 
technology and digital solutions; and climate resilience and disaster risk management systems. 
The TA team will conduct the selection of five cities and specific interventions in close consultation 
with the ADB operations departments based on criteria such as active ADB presence, strategic 
importance to ADB operations, strong government will for  integrated and innovative urban 
solutions, geographic balance, and city size (e.g., secondary cities).12  
                                                
10  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
11  City action plans may be developed in the form of smart city action plans, green city action plans, transit-oriented 
city action plans, localizing Sustainable Development Goals action plans, low-carbon urban transformation action 
plans, inclusive city action plans, competitive city action plans, among others, which are appropriate for the selected 
cities. 
12 The TA team will attempt regional balance. However, eight DMCs (Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Myanmar, Nepal, 
Pakistan, Philippines, and Viet Nam) supported by the Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund will be prioritized 
while other DMCs will be supported by E-Asia Knowledge Partnership Fund.

4 
11.  Output  2:  Asian  Development  Bank  projects  incorporating  integrated  and 
innovative urban solutions for selected cities supported. This will include support for selected 
cities in DMCs to incorporate integrated and innovative livability solutions in ADB’s ongoing or 
new projects in cross-sector and cross-thematic areas such as climate change, education, energy, 
environment, finance, gender, health, heritage conservation and sustainable tourism, housing, 
smart systems, social protection, transport, and water.13 The TA team will select projects that 
(i)  are  directly  linked  to  the  Operational  Plan  for  Priority  4:  Making  Cities  More  Livable 
(footnote 2); (ii) include integrated components; (iii) contain innovative solutions; (iv) include smart 
digital solutions; (v) incorporate inclusive and gender-responsive approaches and (vi) have 
potential for generating knowledge solutions for replication and informing future project design or 
implementation. The TA team will determine the projects to support under this output in close 
consultation with the ADB operations departments. 
 
12.  Output 3: Knowledge and capacities of select cities on livability improved. This will 
include capturing lessons and good practices from the implementation of various ADB projects 
on livable cities, including projects under outputs 1 and 2. The scope includes capacity building 
of key stakeholders in DMC cities to enhance urban livability and sustainability of integrated and 
innovative urban solutions through sharing of best practices and diverse methodologies. The TA 
will  support the  preparation  of knowledge  products  in the  form  of  publications, guidelines, 
multimedia products, and presentations and dissemination of knowledge through knowledge 
events, online and offline vehicles, and other means. The TA team will also encourage and 
document city-to-city learning.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.5 million, of which (i) $2.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Urban  Climate  Change  Resilience  Trust  Fund14 under  the  Urban  Financing 
Partnership Facility and (ii) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea 
e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, both to be administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer this TA and will be the executing agency. The Urban Sector Group 
under the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will be responsible for the 
administration and supervision of the TA. ADB will engage international consultants and national 
consultants and actively engage its operations departments in producing the outputs.  
   
                                                
13  Possible activities include analytical and technical work, due diligence and project preparation, and support for 
developing concepts for integrated and innovative solutions to existing or planned projects. Implementation will be 
up to respective operations departments through their respective projects. 
14  Financing partners: the Rockefeller Foundation, and the governments of Switzerland and the United Kingdom.

5

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement

Management Department. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved 
(i) the Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Urban Climate Change Resilience 
Trust Fund under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility and (ii) ADB administering technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  for  Integrated  and  Innovative 
Solutions for More Livable Cities, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
